name: Jessica Stockholder, The Squared Circle: Ringing
description:
We are thrilled to present a major new commission by the groundbreaking American-Canadian artist Jessica Stockholder, “The Squared Circle: Ringing.”

This spring, visitors on Floor 1 are invited to experience a new large-scale, site-specific artwork by Stockholder, alongside a series of text-based gestures. Revisiting elements from her 2021 installation “Cut a rug a round square,” Stockholder will further explore the interplay between material, colour, and perspective to transform the space into an immersive experience. Incorporating poetic writing into her practice, she will engage with the museum’s various messages, altering and interrupting them to shift viewers’ attention toward the formal beauty and complexity of language.

name: Cultural Hotspot Ignite Ideation Funding: Information Sessions
description:
Join us for an informative session on our Ignite Ideation Funding capacity-building grant. We're excited to offer this opportunity for artists, creatives, artist collectives, grassroots and resident-led groups and small to midsized community organizations based in, or who may have been displaced from, living or working in Kingston-Galloway/Orton Park (KGO) for any reason. We are offering $2,500 to $5,000 per successful proposal. 

During a session, participants will learn about the objectives and eligibility criteria of Ignite Ideation Funding, gain insights into the application process, including tips for crafting a competitive proposal, hear success stories from past grant recipients and learn from their experiences, engage in a Q&A session with the Cultural Hotspot team to clarify any doubts or queries, network with fellow KGO artists, creatives and art administrators to foster collaboration and community building. Applications close June 2 by 4:59 pm.

name: Cherry Blossom Season at Colborne Lodge
description:
Come to Colborne Lodge to celebrate Cherry Blossom season! Sakura Hanami is the Japanese tradition of going to experience the wonderful cherry blossoms in spring and in English translates to "cherry blossom viewing". Learn about the history of the cherry trees in High Park and enjoy reproductions of 19th century Japanese art and poetry depicting this seasonal celebration. Check out haikus created by High Park visitors and add your own haiku to the display. 

For $5, make your own Sakura souvenir.  Materials, instructions, and a space to get crafty are provided.

name: Expression and Freedom-David Adshade
description: Expression and Freedom is a solo retrospective art exhibition hosted by Toronto artist David Adshade. David brings over 20 years of experimenting in the realm of Industrial Abstraction to this innovative and one-of-a-kind visual experience. This show is not to be missed!

name: Justin Ming Yong: Blur
description:
Toronto-based textile artist Justin Ming Yong, unveils “Blur” this spring. This exciting site-specific project by Yong will transform the museum’s elevators as well as the North End Gallery into immersive art spaces. 

Yong has developed a textile practice that reinterprets traditional quilt-making—a craft passed down to him by his mother, an avid quilt-maker. This practice, rooted in centuries-old cultural traditions, considers the interplay of colour, pattern, and geometry. His works, crafted from diverse materials and layered prints, balance harmony and tension, resulting in abstract compositions that are both gestural and hard-edged.

Explore “Blur” and see how Yong’s vibrant quilts reshape familiar spaces.
